Award.AwardTitle: Conference Participation Support Proposal - 22nd Annual Conference Experience for Undergraduates; Crystal City, VA, 13-17 October 2019
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award will provide funds to partially support the 22nd annual Conference Experience for Undergraduates (CEU), which will be held as part of the Fall Meeting of the APS Division of Nuclear Physics. This meeting will be held in Crystal City, VA October 13 - 17, 2019. The CEU is a natural venue for students who have had an undergraduate research experience to present the results of their research and interact with other students as well as faculty and senior researchers. The CEU has been immensely successful in fostering this interaction, which helps students to have a broad introduction and exposure to research across nuclear physics, and to enable senior researchers to get to know some of the junior future leaders. Partial support will be provided for approximately 20 undergraduate students, out of a planned total of 140.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This grant provided partial support for some of the 130 undergraduate students who presented their research in a poster session as part of the 22nd Conference Experience for Undergraduate (CEU) program which was held during the American Physical Society Division of Nuclear Physics (DNP) annual fall meeting. The DNP took place in Crystal City, VA over five days in October 2019.

Undergraduate students attended the full DNP conference program, allowing ample time to discuss physics with other conference participants, and presented their research in a special poster session. The program also included two lectures by leading physicists from Jefferson Laboratory and TRIUMF, a tutorial on how to apply to graduate school, information on nuclear physics graduate schools, and a variety of community building activities.

All of the surveyed students thought their research was valued by the nuclear community and felt they developed valuable presentation skills. In addition, over 60% of students reported an increased interest in nuclear science after attending the CEU program. This program has been successful in encouraging students to further their education in physics. The post conference survey found an 8% increase of students interested in PhD programs in physics or chemistry. In addition, all students would recommend this program to others.
